historicalFigures.name: Ned Kelly
historicalFigures.background: Ned Kelly was a bushranger and outlaw who became a folk hero. He led the Kelly Gang and is famous for wearing a suit of bulletproof armor during his final shootout.
achievements: Subject of the first feature film ever made.
historicalFigures.legacy: Ned Kelly is the Australian Robin Hood. His last words 'Such is life' are legendary.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His armor is a national icon.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as a cop killer by some.

historicalFigures.name: Sir Donald Bradman
historicalFigures.background: Sir Donald Bradman, nicknamed 'The Don', is widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time. His career Test batting average of 99.94 is cited as the greatest achievement by any sportsman in any major sport.
keyDecisions: Practicing with a golf ball and a stump.
historicalFigures.legacy: The Don is the standard of excellence. He is more than a cricketer; he is a symbol of Australia.
quotes: Every ball went exactly where I wanted it to go.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His address was simply 'The Don, Adelaide'.

historicalFigures.name: Edith Cowan
historicalFigures.background: Edith Cowan was a social reformer and the first woman elected to an Australian parliament. She worked tirelessly for the rights of women and children.
historicalFigures.legacy: Edith Cowan broke the glass ceiling. She is featured on the $50 note.
quotes: Women must be ready to take their part.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She paved the way for women in politics.

historicalFigures.name: Vincent Lingiari
historicalFigures.background: Vincent Lingiari was a Gurindji rights activist. He led the Wave Hill walk-off, a strike by Indigenous workers that became a catalyst for the Aboriginal land rights movement.
keyDecisions: Demanding land rights, not just wages.
Accepting the soil from Gough Whitlam.
achievements: AM (Member of the Order of Australia).
historicalFigures.legacy: Lingiari is a giant of Indigenous history. The song 'From Little Things Big Things Grow' tells his story.
quotes: We want to live on our land.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He changed the law and the nation.

historicalFigures.name: Steve Irwin
historicalFigures.background: Steve Irwin, known as 'The Crocodile Hunter', was a zookeeper and television personality. His enthusiastic style and work with wildlife made him a global icon.
historicalFigures.legacy: Steve Irwin put Australian wildlife on the map. His catchphrase 'Crikey!' is world-famous.

historicalFigures.name: Dame Nellie Melba
historicalFigures.background: Dame Nellie Melba was an operatic soprano. She was one of the most famous singers of the late Victorian era and the first Australian to achieve international recognition as a classical musician.
keyDecisions: Conquering Covent Garden and the Met.
historicalFigures.legacy: Melba put Australia on the cultural map. Peach Melba and Melba Toast are named after her.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is a legend of opera.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a queen of song.

historicalFigures.name: Sir John Monash
historicalFigures.background: Sir John Monash was a civil engineer and military commander of the First World War. He commanded the Australian Corps and is considered one of the best generals of the war.
historicalFigures.legacy: Monash is the greatest Australian soldier. He proved that colonials could lead.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Monash University is named after him.

historicalFigures.name: Cathy Freeman
historicalFigures.background: Cathy Freeman is a former sprinter. She won the gold medal in the 400m at the 2000 Sydney Olympics, a moment that united the nation.
historicalFigures.legacy: Cathy Freeman is the face of modern Australia. Her victory in 2000 is the country's greatest sporting moment.
modernInterpretations: Her impact on Indigenous pride is immeasurable.

historicalFigures.name: Gough Whitlam
historicalFigures.background: Gough Whitlam was the 21st Prime Minister of Australia. His government introduced sweeping reforms, including universal healthcare (Medicare) and free university education.
historicalFigures.legacy: Whitlam is the giant of Australian politics. 'It's Time' was his slogan, and he changed the country forever.
quotes: Well may we say 'God save the Queen', because nothing will save the Governor-General.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a hero to the left.
modernInterpretations: His dismissal remains the most controversial event in Australian political history.

historicalFigures.name: Banjo Paterson
historicalFigures.background: Banjo Paterson was a bush poet, journalist, and author. He wrote 'Waltzing Matilda' and 'The Man from Snowy River', capturing the spirit of the Australian outback.
challenges: The decline of the bush lifestyle.
historicalFigures.legacy: Banjo Paterson defined the Australian identity. His poems are recited in schools across the country.
quotes: There was movement at the station.
modernInterpretations: His romantic view of the bush is iconic.

historicalFigures.name: Mary MacKillop
historicalFigures.nativeName: Mary Helen MacKillop (Saint Mary of the Cross)
historicalFigures.background: Mary MacKillop was a nun and the co-founder of the Sisters of St Joseph of the Sacred Heart. She is Australia's first and only canonized saint.
keyDecisions: Founding an order to educate the poor.
Refusing to be controlled by bishops.
historicalFigures.legacy: Mary MacKillop is the saint of the underdog. She stood up to the hierarchy for what was right.
quotes: Never see a need without doing something about it.

historicalFigures.name: Eddie Mabo
historicalFigures.background: Eddie Mabo was an Indigenous rights activist from the Torres Strait Islands. His legal challenge led to the High Court decision overturning 'terra nullius'.
keyDecisions: Taking the case to the High Court.
Fighting for land rights on Mer (Murray Island).
Dying just months before the verdict.
historicalFigures.legacy: Mabo changed the legal foundation of Australia. He proved that the land was occupied before 1788.
modernInterpretations: His name is synonymous with justice.

historicalFigures.name: Sir Douglas Mawson
historicalFigures.background: Sir Douglas Mawson was a geologist and Antarctic explorer. He is famous for his solo survival journey during the Australasian Antarctic Expedition.
keyDecisions: Trekking solo after his companions died.
historicalFigures.legacy: Mawson is the iron man of the ice. His survival story is one of the greatest ever told.
quotes: I am alone on the ice.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a hero of science.

historicalFigures.name: Kylie Minogue
historicalFigures.background: Kylie Minogue is a singer and actress. Known as the 'Princess of Pop', she is the highest-selling female Australian artist of all time.
challenges: Being dismissed as a soap star.
historicalFigures.legacy: Kylie is Australia's sweetheart. She has stayed at the top for 40 years.

historicalFigures.name: Albert Namatjira
historicalFigures.background: Albert Namatjira was an Arrernte painter. He is famous for his watercolours of the Australian outback, which bridged Indigenous and Western art.
achievements: First Indigenous person to be granted citizenship.
historicalFigures.legacy: Namatjira's art is the soul of the center. His tragic life highlighted the injustice of the system.
modernInterpretations: Symbol of the stolen generation era.

historicalFigures.name: Rupert Murdoch
historicalFigures.background: Rupert Murdoch is a media tycoon who built a global empire (News Corp). He owns major newspapers and TV networks in Australia, the UK, and the US.
keyDecisions: Buying The Sun and The Times.
historicalFigures.legacy: Murdoch is the most powerful Australian in history. His influence on global democracy is debated.

historicalFigures.name: Truganini
historicalFigures.background: Truganini was a Palawa woman from Tasmania. She was often incorrectly referred to as the 'last Tasmanian Aboriginal', a label that ignored the survival of her people.
keyDecisions: Living in exile on Flinders Island.
Pleading to be buried in the sea.
challenges: Display of her skeleton (against her will).
historicalFigures.legacy: Truganini is the symbol of the Tasmanian genocide. Her spirit represents survival against odds.
quotes: Don't let them cut me up.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Her skeleton was finally cremated in 1976.
modernInterpretations: Her story is a reminder of colonial horror.

historicalFigures.name: Heath Ledger
historicalFigures.background: Heath Ledger was an actor known for his versatility and intensity. His performance as the Joker in 'The Dark Knight' won him a posthumous Oscar.
historicalFigures.legacy: Heath Ledger was a shooting star. His Joker is considered one of the greatest performances in cinema history.
